author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: How an Obscure Swim Club Got a Say in Choosing Hong Kong’s Leader
description: Beijing is making it nearly impossible for the pro-democracy camp to win city elections. One tool: “grass roots” groups loyal to the government.
content: HONG KONG — The Sea Bear Swimming Club, in the northeastern outskirts of Hong Kong, is a humble organization. It trains children for local competitions and offers free lessons to older adults. Its Facebook page, with just 151 followers, features photos of grinning students in swim caps and the occasional cat meme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Bobby Bowden, Coach Who Led Florida State to Greatness, Dies at 91
description: He transformed the Seminoles into a national powerhouse, and ended his career second only to Joe Paterno in major college football victories.
content: Bobby Bowden, the folksy showman who transformed Florida State University into a national football powerhouse and became the second-winningest coach in the history of major college football, died on Sunday at his home in Tallahassee, Florida. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Cuomo Used A Movement For His Gain
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 8, 2021.
content: “It’s not just about toughening the laws. You also have to change the mind-set of people who may believe that they’re above the law.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: ‘The Most Happy Fella,’ Sliced, Diced and None Too Pleased
description: Having revamped “Oklahoma!” into a dark X-ray of itself, Daniel Fish rethinks another Golden Age classic with “Most Happy in Concert.”
content: RED HOOK, N.Y. — It was useful to remember as I watched “Most Happy in Concert,” the bizarre and fascinating 75-minute cantata that just finished a run here on Saturday evening, that the neatly cut lawn at Montgomery Place, the grand Hudson River estate where the show was performed, does not much resemble the vineyards of Napa Valley. That’s where “The Most Happy Fella,” the 1956 Frank Loesser musical on which the concert was based, takes place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Boyd
title: TikTok, YouTube and Facebook Want to Appear Trustworthy. Don’t Be Fooled.
description: Beware Silicon Valley’s latest trend: fake transparency.
content: TikTok made a big announcement last year. The company would open a Transparency and Accountability Center, giving the public a rare glimpse into how it works, including its algorithm. These A.I.-driven systems are usually black boxes, but TikTok was committed to “leading the way when it comes to being transparent,” it said, providing insight into how and why the algorithm recommends content to users.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aljean Harmetz
title: Jane Withers, Child Star Who Later Won Fame in Commercials, Dies at 95
description: As a girl, she landed leading roles that were the antidote to Shirley Temple’s. As an adult, she was known as Josephine the Plumber in ads for Comet cleanser.
content: Jane Withers, a top child star in the 1930s who played tough, tomboyish brats in more than two dozen B films and achieved a second burst of fame as an adult as Josephine the Plumber in commercials for Comet cleanser, died on Saturday in Burbank, Calif. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee
title: Alibaba Will Fire Employee After Rape Accusation
description: Two senior managers also resigned for failing to respond appropriately after the woman reported the incident, the company’s chief executive said in a memo.
content: The Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba Group told staff members in a memo on Monday morning that it would fire a male employee who was accused of raping a female colleague.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Collin Hansen
title: What We Lose When We Livestream Church
description: Broadcasting religious worship has played an important role during the pandemic. But it's had unintended consequences.
content: Riding around town earlier this year, my 3-year-old daughter shouted, “Look, a church!” It took me a second to understand what she meant. I didn’t see any churches. All I could see was a parking deck. Then I realized my daughter couldn’t remember our church building. Since last summer our church has been meeting under the cover of a parking deck so that we could still assemble in person without wilting in Alabama’s summer sun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: Seven Olympic Moments Worth Revisiting
description: A spicy rhythmic gymnastics finale. A 62-year-old medalist. A former prodigy with a gold. The Olympic magic was spread across sports.
content: Olympic moments abound, whether widely noticed or barely. There were 339 events in 33 sports contested by more than 11,000 athletes at the Tokyo Games, so don’t worry if you couldn’t keep up. Here is just a sampler:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Karen Hastie Williams, Barrier-Breaking Lawyer, Dies at 76
description: She was the first Black woman to serve as a Supreme Court clerk and went on to break countless other glass ceilings, while helping others do the same.
content: The first time Karen Hastie Williams remembered encountering racism was at a meeting with her junior high school guidance counselor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: The Taliban take three more cities.
content: Three cities fell to the insurgent group on Sunday, a staggering advance as government forces struggled to hold the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The ceremony will stream live in the United States, then air tape delayed on NBC.
description: The ceremony in Tokyo starts at 8 p.m. Sunday in Japan, 7 a.m. Eastern time in the United States.
content: The details of the Tokyo Olympics closing ceremony are closely guarded before it begins. And the coronavirus pandemic has changed a lot. But based on the closing ceremonies of the recent past, we can still safely predict some of what we’ll see starting at 8 p.m. Tokyo time on Sunday night (7 a.m. Eastern). There will be music, speeches, anthems and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: U.S. Wins First Olympic Gold in Women’s Volleyball
description: A program with two silvers and a bronze from its three most recent Games claims its first Olympic championship.
content: TOKYO — Every journey up the Olympic mountain comes with a series of incidents that, in retrospect, seems meticulously designed but was in fact just a roll of the dice that paid off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: U.S. Women Win Basketball Gold, and Prepare to Turn the Page
description: Sue Bird and Diana Taurasi collected their fifth gold medals, and then signaled that they would leave the team to a younger generation of stars.
content: SAITAMA, Japan — The members of the U.S. women’s basketball team lined up on the court at Saitama Super Arena, stepped onto the highest podium and raised their hands above their heads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Markie Post, ‘Night Court’ Actress, Dies at 70
description: Ms. Post played a bail bondswoman on the show “The Fall Guy” in the 1980s and starred opposite John Ritter in the sitcom “Hearts Afire” in the 1990s.
content: Markie Post, the effervescent actress known for her roles on the television series “Night Court” and “The Fall Guy” and the movie “There’s Something About Mary” during a career that spanned four decades, died on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Najim Rahim, Sharif Hassan and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: As Afghan Cities Fall to Taliban, Brutal New Chapter Unfolds
description: “This is now a different kind of war, reminiscent of Syria.” The seizure of five capitals has amplified fears about Afghanistan’s future after the U.S. withdrawal.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban seized three Afghan cities on Sunday, including the commercial hub of Kunduz, officials said, escalating a sweeping offensive that has claimed five provincial capitals in three days and shown how little control the government has over the country without American military power to protect it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: One Game, and Tweet, at a Time, the Mets Are Sliding
description: “We have to get our act together soon,” Steven Cohen, the team’s owner, posted during a lost last week. The team is 1-4 since then and has fallen to third in the N.L. East.
content: PHILADELPHIA — We still don’t know the meaning of the missives. When Steven Cohen visits his stumbling Mets in the road clubhouse on a Sunday morning — and tweets about it — is that an act of support, or a sign of panic? When he tweets on Friday that the Mets will start hitting, but instead they look feeble all weekend, will there be repercussions?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Even as Dixie Fire Rages, ‘I’m Not Going to Leave’
description: In Taylorsville, a few residents won’t follow evacuation orders. “These fires, they’re never going to get me.”
content: TAYLORSVILLE, Calif. — The Dixie Fire, now the second-largest in California’s history, is still raging across the tinder-dry forest of the Sierra Nevada mountains. In its wake, the town of Greenville has been reduced to scattered bricks and crumpled sheets of metal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Kathy Hochul, Cuomo’s No. 2, Quietly Prepares to Step Into the Limelight
description: After working mostly in the background since joining Gov. Andrew Cuomo’s team in 2014, Ms. Hochul is poised to replace him if he steps down or is forced out.
content: When Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was holding his marathon sessions of news briefings during the peak of the coronavirus crisis, he was often flanked by his closest aides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: TikTok Trend: Eating Frozen Honey and Risking Ill Effects
description: Like some social media trends, this one has its problems, including stomach aches, diarrhea and bad teeth, health experts said.
content: Dave Ramirez squeezed the frozen bottle with both hands, watching the golden goop come out like toothpaste. Then, he took a big sticky bite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Tokyo Games wrap up with a few more big wins.
description: The United States won gold in women’s basketball and volleyball, and Eliud Kipchoge of Kenya defended his Olympic marathon title.
content: TOKYO — There was a smaller menu on the last day of this most unusual Olympics, but it was an elite one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Yu and Talya Minsberg
title: A look at all of the world records that were broken at the Tokyo Olympics.
description: Records fell in multiple sports at these Games despite brutal conditions and a year’s delay.
content: TOKYO — World records are bound to fall at every Olympics, when the world’s greatest athletes compete on one stage and are pushed further and faster by advances in technology. Yet many also wondered whether swampy conditions in and around Tokyo — and the impact of a year’s delay — would hinder the expected monumental performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Live Music Is Back! (Live Music Is Back?)
description: As the concert business amped up again, our critic booked six weeks seeing shows in honky-tonks, clubs and arenas. But concerns about Covid-19 became the unannounced guest on nearly every lineup.
content: I’ll confess up front that I walked into the Jacob Collier show at the Blue Note New York with some apprehension.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: New Orleans Jazz Fest is canceled amid rise in virus cases.
description: The festival had been moved to the fall in the hope that vaccinations would make the event possible.
content: The New Orleans Jazz & Heritage Festival has been canceled, officials said Sunday, citing the “exponential growth of new Covid cases in New Orleans and the region.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Arkansas’ governor says it ‘was an error’ to ban mask mandates.
description: Gov. Asa Hutchinson is working to modify a bill he signed in April in the wake of rising case counts and outbreaks at schools.
content: Gov. Asa Hutchinson of Arkansas said on Sunday that he had made a mistake in signing a law banning mask mandates in his state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Olympics End as They Began: Strangely
description: The 32nd Summer Olympics came to a close in Tokyo. “We did it — together!” the president of the International Olympic Committee said, to lukewarm applause.
content: TOKYO — As the athletes finished marching into the stadium for the closing ceremony of the 32nd Summer Olympics on Sunday night, the announcer asked for a big round of applause. But there simply weren’t enough people in the stands to make much noise. And the flashiest component of the ceremony, a formation of the five Olympic rings by tiny points of light, was invisible live in the stadium. The magic of its special effects played only on large screens and to television audiences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Dennis ‘Dee Tee’ Thomas, Saxophonist for Kool & the Gang, Dies at 70
description: Mr. Thomas was a co-founder of the band, which was known for its hits such as “Celebration,” “Get Down on It” and “Jungle Boogie.”
content: Dennis “Dee Tee” Thomas, a saxophonist and a founding member of the band Kool & the Gang, died on Saturday in New Jersey. He was 70.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Eliud Kipchoge Wins Olympic Marathon Again, Securing His Legacy
description: The Kenyan pulled away from the pack and ran alone for the final eight-plus miles, becoming only the third man to win gold medals in back-to-back Olympics.
content: Eliud Kipchoge, 36, of Kenya won his second consecutive Olympic marathon on Sunday in 2 hours 8 minutes 38 seconds, reaffirming his status as the greatest runner in history over the distance of 26.2 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Andrew Sullivan, No One’s Ally, Tells It as He Sees It
description: Sullivan’s new collection, “Out on a Limb,” traces his opinions and battles across 32 tumultuous years.
content: OUT ON A LIMBSelected Writing, 1989-2021By Andrew Sullivan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Here’s what to watch for at the closing ceremony.
description: There will be music and speeches, and a handoff to Paris for the 2024 Games.
content: The details of the Tokyo Olympics closing ceremony are closely guarded before it begins. But based on the closing ceremonies of the recent past, we can still safely predict some of what we’ll see starting at 8 p.m. Tokyo time on Sunday night (7 a.m. Eastern). Follow our live updates here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Anthony Rizzo Is Latest Yankee to Test Positive for Coronavirus
description: The newly acquired first baseman told reporters in June that he was not yet vaccinated, saying he was waiting to see more data.
content: Anthony Rizzo, the first baseman acquired by the Yankees at the trading deadline, has tested positive for the coronavirus and was placed on the Covid-19 injured list by the team on Sunday, Manager Aaron Boone said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Katie Rogers and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: As Taliban Capture Cities, U.S. Says Afghan Forces Must Fend for Themselves
description: The muted American response to the Taliban siege shows in no uncertain terms that the U.S. war in Afghanistan is over.
content: WASHINGTON — If the Taliban had seized three provincial capitals in northern Afghanistan a year ago, like they did on Sunday, the American response would most likely have been ferocious. Fighter jets and helicopter gunships would have responded in force, beating back the Islamist group or, at the very least, stalling its advance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa and Jacey Fortin
title: As R. Kelly’s Trial Begins, Here’s a Timeline of the Allegations
description: The R&B singer has faced a trail of accusations since 1996. On Monday, he goes on trial in Brooklyn.
content: For two and a half decades, the singer who performs as R. Kelly has faced allegations of sexually abusing minors, often luring them in through music — and the promise to help launch their own music careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Najim Rahim and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: The fall of Sar-i-Pul threatens a commercial hub in Afghanistan’s north.
description: The Taliban went all-out in recent days to seize Sar-i-Pul, putting even more pressure on Mazar-i-Sharif to its east.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — Of the three cities seized by the Taliban in northern Afghanistan on Sunday, Sar-i-Pul, the capital of the province with the same name, garnered fewer headlines and less concern from the international community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Here Come the Mandates
description: Governments and companies have started to require vaccines, a step they had been reluctant to take until recently.
content: As coronavirus cases surged again among the unvaccinated, governments and companies started mandating vaccines, a step they had been reluctant to take until recently. New York City said indoor dining, performances and gyms would require proof of at least one dose starting Aug. 16. Microsoft will require proof of vaccination to enter its U.S. offices, and Tyson will require all its U.S. workers to be vaccinated, as will United Airlines. Other companies mandated vaccines for some, but not all, of their workers. Walmart will require vaccines for employees at its headquarters but not the far greater number of employees who work in its stores. Mandates may soon be made easier: The Food and Drug Administration said on Tuesday that it planned to give final approval to the Pfizer vaccine by the start of next month.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Despite Threat of Prison, a Survivor of Cambodia’s Genocide Stands Firm
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, August 7, 2021.
content: “It’s like showing you have a conscience.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: For Seniors Especially, Covid Can Be Stealthy
description: With infections increasing once more, and hospitalization rising among older adults, health experts offer a timely warning: a coronavirus infection can look different in older patients.
content: One day in March of 2020, Rosemary Bily suddenly grew so tired she could barely get out of bed. “She slept a lot,” said her son-in-law Rich Lamanno. “She was wiped out for most of a month.” Ms. Bily, now 86, also developed nausea and diarrhea, along with a slight cough, and subsisted mostly on Tylenol and Gatorade.
source.name: The New York Times

title: With More Freedom, Young Women in Albania Shun Tradition of ‘Sworn Virgins’
description: A centuries-old tradition in which women declared themselves men so they could enjoy male privilege is dying out as young women have more options available to them to live their own lives.
content: LEPUSHE, Albania — As a teenager locked in a patriarchal and tradition-bound mountain village in the far north of Albania, Gjystina Grishaj made a drastic decision: She would live the rest of her life as a man.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum, Najim Rahim, Sharif Hassan and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: The Taliban fly their flag in Kunduz as exhausted Afghan troops regroup.
description: The rapid fall of important Afghan cities comes as insurgent fighters have pressed their offensive all around the country, dividing Afghan forces as U.S. troops depart.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban seized a major strategic and propaganda prize early Sunday, capturing the crucial northern commercial hub of Kunduz and then breaking through in two other regional capitals later the same day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein
title: Executive Assistant Who Accused Cuomo of Groping Comes Forward
description: “What he did to me was a crime,” said Brittany Commisso, identified in a report from the state attorney general as “Executive Assistant #1.”
content: The executive assistant who accused Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of repeatedly groping her and who filed a criminal complaint against him has come forward in an interview to be aired on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: The U.S. edges China for the most gold medals.
description: The countries were in a tight race on the final day of the Olympics for the most golds, and it could have gone either way.
content: The United States has won the most medals at the Tokyo Olympics and will be the only country to take home more than 100. But on the last day of competition, the race for the most gold medals was a tight contest between the United States and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Cappelle
title: Leïla Slimani Has Written About a Sex Addict and a Murderous Nanny. Next Up: Her Own Family.
description: Slimani’s new novel, “In the Country of Others,” is modeled on her grandmother’s immigration from France to Morocco amid Morocco’s fight for independence.
content: PARIS  — “In the Country of Others,” the French-Moroccan author Leïla Slimani’s latest book, is an unorthodox immigration story. The central character, Mathilde, is a blond Frenchwoman — modeled after Slimani’s grandmother — who meets a Moroccan soldier during World War II. She follows him back to his country, then a French colony, where she finds herself the unwanted outsider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: ‘This Is Really Scary’: Kids Struggle With Long Covid
description: Lingering physical, mental and neurological symptoms are affecting children as well as adults, including many who had mild reactions to the initial coronavirus infection.
content: Will Grogan stared blankly at his ninth-grade biology classwork. It was material he had mastered the day before, but it looked utterly unfamiliar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Delta Variant, Wildfires, Tokyo Olympics: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Every Subway Trip Started With Me Taking the B or C to 59th Street’
description: A ride to Brooklyn and back, an unlikely lift at a low moment and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Fires Continue to Ravage Greece Amid Europe’s Protracted Heat Wave
description: Multiple countries are sending firefighting aid to Greece as blazes rage for a sixth day.
content: ATHENS — Huge wildfires raged for a sixth day on Sunday in several parts of Greece, forcing thousands more people from their homes and razing vast tracts of forestland, with even more countries having stepped in to help the Greek firefighting effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Najim Rahim and Sharif Hassan
title: Another provincial capital, Taliqan, falls to the insurgents on Sunday.
description: The Taliban seize a third regional capital in just one day, tightening their hold on a vast swath of northern Afghanistan.
content: Taliban fighters captured another northern provincial capital on Sunday afternoon, local officials said, marking the third city to fall to the insurgent group in a single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Olympic rings floating above the stadium were purely special effects for TV.
description: People inside the stadium did not see them.
content: How may different ways can the Olympic rings be displayed? Let’s see, you could do it with flame, luminescent shapes, costumed performers, fireworks … yeah those have all been done. With the Games coming every two years (uh, usually), original ideas must be hard to come up with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Melina Delkic
title: Dixie Fire Is Now Second Largest in California History
description: The fire blazing across Northern California has burned more than 463,000 acres.
content: TAYLORSVILLE, Calif. — The Dixie Fire ravaging Northern California over the weekend has become the state’s second largest on record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter and Fahim Abed
title: The Propaganda War Intensifies in Afghanistan as the Taliban Gain Ground
description: The effort to fend off panic and minimize losses has taken on outsize importance following the seizure of five provincial capitals by the Taliban.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — First, a remote provincial capital in Afghanistan’s southwest fell. The next day, it was a city in Afghanistan’s north. By Sunday, Taliban fighters had taken three more cities, including their biggest prize yet, the major provincial capital of Kunduz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Just for the Fun of It
description: Alex Eaton-Salners makes some impressive logical leaps.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — When you’re eight years old, the height of comedy is telling your friends, your parents and your teachers that it isn’t opposite day. I remember giddily going through the logical twists and turns of “wait … I mean … it is synonym night? Or is it … not opposite not day?” and so on, ad infinitum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim
title: When cities are falling to the Taliban, what happens next can vary.
description: What does it look like when a city falls in Afghanistan?
content: What does it look like when a city falls in Afghanistan?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: New York in Party Mode (Briefly): Behind the Metro Desk’s Nightlife Project
description: Nearly 50 journalists spent weeks documenting what New Yorkers were doing after dark when pandemic restrictions were fading, at least for a time.
content: There were a lot of late nights. Even nights that became mornings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: After Trumka’s Death, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Faces a Crossroads
description: For years, influencing political outcomes has been the priority. Some are calling for more emphasis on basic organizing.
content: Richard Trumka’s 12 years as A.F.L.-C.I.O. president coincided with the continued decline of organized labor but also moments of opportunity, like the election of a devoutly pro-labor U.S. president. With Mr. Trumka’s death last week, the federation faces a fundamental question: What is the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s purpose?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Anti-Vax Insanity
description: There are Americans who are determined to prove that they are right, even if it puts them on the wrong side of a eulogy.
content: Nothing better exemplifies the gaping political divide in this country than our embarrassing and asinine vaccine response. Donald Trump’s scorched earth political strategy has fooled millions of Americans into flirting with death. And now thousands are once again dying for it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Marc Lieberman, Who Brought Jews and Buddhists Together, Dies at 72
description: He called himself “a healthy mosaic” of the two faiths. An ophthalmologist, he also ran a clinic that brought sight back to Tibetans with cataracts.
content: Dr. Marc Lieberman, an ophthalmologist and self-proclaimed “Jewish Buddhist” who, when he wasn’t treating glaucoma, organized a dialogue between Jewish scholars and the Dalai Lama, and who later brought sight back to thousands of Tibetans stricken by cataracts, died on Aug. 2 at his home in San Francisco. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Man Who Filed More Than 180 Disability Lawsuits’
description: Is it profiteering — or justice?
content: For much of America’s history, a person with a disability had few civil rights related to their disability. That began to change when, in the 1980s, a group of lawmakers started to agitate for sweeping civil rights legislation, akin to the Civil Rights Act of 1964, on behalf of people with disabilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: San Francisco’s Cyclists Cheer a Road Less Traveled. Museums Mourn It.
description: Though pedestrians and cyclists are rejoicing at a Golden Gate Park ban on cars, rebounding museums fear the detour will keep visitors away.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — From the top of the Hamon Observation Tower at the de Young Museum, with its sweeping views of San Francisco, John F. Kennedy Drive cuts a gentle curve through Golden Gate Park below. It is, these days, a road without cars, set aside for pedestrians and bicyclists since the beginning of the pandemic, which forced the museum to shut down for nearly a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Saudi Aramco Posts $25 Billion Profit
description: The world’s oil giants are bouncing back, aided by accelerating economies in crucial markets.
content: DUBAI — Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, reported a nearly fourfold rise in second-quarter net profit on Sunday, bolstered by higher oil prices and a recovery in oil demand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
title: Senate Works on Infrastructure ‘the Old-Fashioned Way’: Painfully Slow
description: The bipartisan bill has resurrected the lost art of freewheeling legislative debate in the usually gridlocked chamber. It takes forever.
content: WASHINGTON — As senators spent the first Sunday of what was supposed to be their summer break casting evening votes on a $1 trillion infrastructure bill whose passage now seems all but assured, it was hard not to notice the frustration setting in.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Hearing Their Footsteps, Sharing Their Joy
description: Track and field at the Tokyo Games helped fill the final 10 days of the Olympic schedule, and five years — in so many ways — was worth the wait.
content: TOKYO — It was a week and a half of extremes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Jacob Desvarieux, Guitarist Who Forged Zouk Style, Dies at 65
description: His band, Kassav’, found millions of listeners as it held on to Caribbean roots while reaching out to the world. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Molly Seidel ran her third marathon, got bronze, and was honored at the closing ceremony.
description: It was only the third time an American woman reached the podium in the Olympic marathon. And that podium was put on the Tokyo Games’ biggest stage.
content: On Saturday morning in Sapporo, about 500 miles north of Tokyo, Molly Seidel of the United States ran her third marathon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeneen Interlandi
title: In the Opioid Epidemic, More Reasons for Hope Than Despair
description: After years of dithering and a surge in overdose deaths, we have an administration that seems able to distinguish between effective and ineffective approaches.
content: It’s been more than two decades since Purdue Pharma released its patented pain medication OxyContin to an unsuspecting public. Since then, more than 500,000 people have died in the United States in an addiction and overdose crisis triggered by the excessive marketing and overuse of that drug and others like it. Thousands of lawsuits have been filed against Purdue and other opioid makers, but for the most part only small-time scapegoats — street dealers and opioid users — have truly been held to account for the epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Eduardo Medina
title: Black Real Estate Agent and Clients Handcuffed at House Viewing
description: The real estate agent was showing his clients, who are also Black, a house in Wyoming, Mich., when the police were called.
content: The house on Sharon Avenue in Wyoming, Mich., was supposed to be another option for Eric Brown, a real estate agent, to show to his client.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: J.D. Vance Converted to Trumpism. Will Ohio Republicans Buy It?
description: As the “Hillbilly Elegy” author runs for Senate in Ohio, he has walked back previous criticism of Donald Trump and reversed arguments that the white working class bears responsibility for its problems.
content: Before he was a celebrity supporter of Donald J. Trump’s, J.D. Vance was one of his most celebrated critics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Eliud Kipchoge finishes far ahead of the pack to defend his men’s Olympic marathon title.
description: Kipchoge, the world’s most decorated marathoner, finished the race in 2 hours 8 minutes and 38 seconds.
content: Eliud Kipchoge, 36, of Kenya won his second consecutive Olympic marathon on Sunday in 2 hours 8 minutes 38 seconds, reaffirming his status as the greatest runner in history over the distance of 26.2 miles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: American boxers post their best showing since 2000.
description: With four medals, the United States posted its best Olympic performance in the ring in two decades.
content: TOKYO — The United States claimed two medals in boxing on the last day of the Olympics as the lightweight Keyshawn Davis and Richard Torrez Jr., a super heavyweight, earned silver medals.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Biggest Highlights From the Oddest Olympics
description: See the action from inside the Tokyo Games’ anti-pandemic bubble — including a few things you might have missed.
content: See the action from inside the Tokyo Games’ anti-pandemic bubble — including a few things you might have missed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Wildfire Scorches the Greek Island of Evia
description: The island endured the worst of the fires on Sunday, as evacuations continued for northern villages.
content: The island endured the worst of the fires on Sunday, as evacuations continued for northern villages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Make chicken salad for dinner tonight and lunch this week, then give a sweet corn and scallop pasta a spin.
content: Good morning. I worked for a while at a restaurant that had a small commissary attached to it: boxed meals and salads and soups for the sort of people who love good food but have no time to make it, or have the time but no desire to use it cooking. It was a kind of an urban Loaves & Fishes, where the more we charged for chicken salad, the more of it we sold.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 7, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Aug. 7, 2021.
content: An article on Thursday about a debate over presidential war powers misidentified which Senate committee voted on legislation repealing two authorizations for use of military force. It was the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, not the Senate Armed Services Committee.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Smartphone Addiction Among the Young
description: Readers offer insights and solutions to a ubiquitous problem. Also: The importance of cash; listening to the birds.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 8, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 8, 2021.
content: A picture caption in an article last weekend about Muammar el-Qaddafi’s son Seif misidentified pieces of ammunition found in Ain Zara, Libya. They are mortar shells, not artillery shells.
source.name: The New York Times
